urlLink AlterNet -- Bush 'Unsigns' War Crimes Treaty [Undersecretary of State for Arms Control and International Security, John Bolton] also helped draft a pending bill in Congress, the American Servicemen's Protection Act (ASPA), which not only bars any U.S. cooperation with the court, but also bars U.S. military aid to other countries unless they agree to shield U.S. troops on their territory from ICC prosecution. It also bans U.S. troops from taking part in UN peacekeeping operations unless the UN Security Council explicitly exempts them from possible prosecution. One version of the bill, which is still being discussed in Congress, would open the way for the president to use force to free U.S. prisoners hauled before the ICC, which is to be located at The Hague, in the Netherlands. - in which case the policy of the US government, in the event of US personnel being held for trial for war crimes, would be to send special forces to the Hague to bust them out. Way to go, George - that'll totally reach the old hearts and minds, as regards respect for the rule of law... (Alternet via wood s lot)

urlLink Salon.com Technology | File sharing: Innocent until proven guilty - Stan Liebowitz, a professor of managerial economics at the University of Texas at Dallas, says music piracy should be hurting the recording industry, but it isn't -- and he doesn't know why. Actually, "music piracy" is the wording provided by Salon's sub-editorsp; "file sharing" would be a more accurate description of Liebowitz's subject. Right off the top of my head, I'd hazard that the record industry can survive as long as they add value to the packaged music they sell - the music industry has never made music as such, it makes packages of music, and most people aren't inclined to make their own packages. urlLink About five years ago, curious about the provenance of the song "Nature Boy", I cast about for information on that interweb thing, and didn't get very far at all. This evening, however, prompted by Audion's shuffle-play shuffling across Alex Chilton's lovely version, I tried again. Connoisseurs of extremely odd marginal figures in music may already know that the song was written by urlLink Eden Ahbez , Brooklyn born ascetic mystic, who persuaded Nat King Cole to record the tune. It became a massive hit. He subsequently fell out of the music industry, as he would, until the 60s, when he was persuaded into studios in Los Angeles to record urlLink Eden's Island (reissued by REsearch as part of their Incredibly Strange CDs series). There are unreleased fragments of music and poetry by the man urlLink here - definitely hear the first piece on the page, which is a retelling of the (possibly autobiographical) "Nature Boy" story... Oh and, tantalisingly, the spaceagepop.com biography hints that Ahbez was to be seen in the company of Brian Wilson shortly before the Pet Sounds sessions...!

I'm pretty certain that this was blogged here and there quite a while ago, because that was how I first came across it, at least eighteen months ago, but picking up on speculation about something weird happening in the deep oceans led me back to the urlLink IRIS Seismic Monitor . This is a world map showing the epicentre of each seismic event (earthquake) over the last five years, up to 30 minutes ago. Since I last visited, they've built a new version, which is urlLink here , and which opens a Gooogle search page for seismic activity in the region where you choose to zoom in. Very cool indeed. These maps show most clearly how and where the surface of the earth is constantly remaking itself: the purple dots that mark the site of older tremors trace out the fault lines between the tectonic plates that comprise the earth's crust.

The latest copy of urlLink The Wire landed on my doormat this morning, and within, the regular Invisible Jukebox features Arthur Lee of Love. The introductory paragraph stopped me in my tracks - it seems that one Peter Bradley MP entered an Early Day Motion to the House of Commons, inviting the House to acknowledge the status of Forever Changes as the Greatest Rock Album of Alll Time. WTF? I mean, the claim itslef has considerable merit, but surely they're not proposing to debate this in the House? Further researches reveal the following in Hansard: 1369 ARTHUR LEE, LOVE AND FOREVER CHANGES 22:5:02 Peter Bradley * 1 That this House pays tribute to the legendary Arthur Lee, also known as Arthurly, frontman and inspiration of Love, the world's greatest rock band and creators of Forever Changes, the greatest album of all time; notes that following his release from jail he is currently touring Europe; and urges honourable and especially Right honourable Members to consider the potential benefit to their constituents if they were, with the indulgence of their whips, to lighten up and tune in to one of his forthcoming British gigs. You can see the record for yourself urlLink here - but I should mention that this page crashed my machine twice when browsed with MSIE (Mac), and only obliged with a result when I switched to Mozilla. Your mileage, as they say, may vary. (EDMs, by the way, are a species of motion that rarely get any floor time to speak of - they're usually squeezed out by more pressing business, so we're unlikely to see this actually debated... well, now I think I'll go and see what I can find about Peter Bradley MP. Catch you later...) UPDATE : Here we are - pages about Peter Bradley from urlLink The Guardian , including his entries in the Register of Member's Interests. Labour, The Wrekin, maj. 3587. Nothing about big production psychedelic rock in there. He's conspicuously anti-foxhunting, though - or should that be pro-fox? I'm not down with the terminology in this area...

urlLink This Machine Kills Fascists: Why sub-culture no longer exists, by Nicholas Rombes - "The frantic replication of reality on TV shows and in movies desperately and unsuccessfully masks the truth that the real is running out -- it's practically all used up." I think Rombes is saying that subculture (meaning, possibly avant garde, possibly "underground" culture) has been, in the language of the Situationists, recuperated. If this is what he's saying, I disagree somewhat, although I'm probably too marginal in my tastes to be able to tell for sure. Certainly the fixed narrative, the authoritative "text" of a movie has become (further) blurred by the advent of the DVD, which at least offers the possibilty of breaking with the traditional linear narrative of movies - but this is an incremental change from VHS (which allowed viewers to pause, rewind, slo-mo...) rather than a radical discontinuity. But the DVD is, in the end, another read-only medium: where things get really interesting with the MPG family, whose progeny are amenable to remixing... There's another recent piece by Rombes at CTheory, urlLink Professor DVD which addresses the threat that the expanded edition DVD, with its on-board commentaries and what-have-you, poses to professorial authority . Most of us, I expect, should be able to contemplate this threat with equanimity?

In Defense of (Some of) The Hundred Albums... For the past few days, a feature on Jaguaro.org, urlLink One Hundred Albums You Should Remove from Your Collection , has done the rounds of the blogosphere. Craig Jensen, whose musical tastes I respect enormously, based on the regular urlLink Featured CDs at Booknotes, owns up to having seventeen of the offending hundred in his collection, and urlLink comments on these, and invites other bloggers to do similar. Since I'd already started doing just that, (and a link from Booknotes would do my traffic no harm at all!) I went ahead with the following. Right, context first. I've been buying music for just about thirty years, and I spent five years as a professional music critic. I possess truly stupid amounts of music, and I'm not that good at getting rid of it, if and when it disappoints. Consequently (?) I have no less than thirty four of the hundred items in Jaguaro's list - if you count vinyl, CDs and MP3 rips - and eight out of Jaguaro's first ten. This could be seen as deplorable. On the other hand, there are 66 records on the list that I have never owned - many of these I'd consider it pretty damning that you would have them in your collection in the first place (I mean, Green Day? Fugazi? Celine Dion? Rush? Do me a favour...!) and a smattering of albums/artists I've never even heard of, so their inclusion in any list of overrated "classics" is extremely moot. Step up and identify yourselves, Paula Cole, Helmet, Death Cab For Cutie, Sublime... So, in approximately ascending order of disagreement with Jaguaro: 3 years 5 months... - this is gone already. Everyday People was good - disposable, brightly coloured pop-rap, sounded okay in the context of joints like De La Soul and PM Dawn's first. The rest of it was very quotidian, and the followup record, whose name I cannot recall, was born to languish in remainder bins. Zen Arcade - bought this at the time of release, more or less, and I've not played it much since, I have to admit. Electric - I have this on vinyl - a promo copy from my days as a music critic. I keep it because the cover is just hilarious, and it's theoretically possible that I would play a track or two in a knowing, ironic sort of a way, for the right audience, but... yeah. I know. The Joshua Tree - vinyl promo copy and a miserably bad pressing into the bargain. I used to use this one as an exemplar of high volume, low quality vinyl production that probably served to drive untold millions of consumers into buying their first CD player. (It didn't work on me - I didn't buy my first CD player for another ten years!). Anyway, I was never that keen on stadium rock. Synchronicity , Zenyatta Mondatta - I didn't think much of the Police while they were together, but as Sting's mostly wretched solo career continued, I came to the conclusion that at least by comparison, the oevre of the Police was respectable and worth investigating. So I allowed secondhand vinyl copies of all the albums to gravitate into my collection, for further study. I have my favourite few tracks, but in most cases I couldn't even tell you which albums they're on, and I have no doubt that a greatest hits would be more than enough. Physical Grafitti - hasn't been off the shelf since I got the Remasters on CD. Only ever played Kashmir anyway, as far as I remember. What's The Story Morning Glory? - some of the singles have a certain leery charm. I still think Don't Look Back In Anger is about as great a record - of its stadium singalong type - as it could possibly be. But Oasis have never made an album I could happily play end to end. Probably I only ever did it once... Emancipation - this was where it became all too obvious that His Elfishness had lost the ability to evaluate his own output. I suspect that if you went through eveything he released from Sign O The Times onwards, it would be possible to come up with a perfectly respectable collection of work - but it would probably take you months and at the end you would hate him anyway for shovelling out so much crap along the way, too. I'll surrender my copy of Emancipation without complaint, but I'll rip his version of Betcha By Golly Wow, and probably a couple of others too before you take it away, if it's all the same to you. Vs. , Midnite Vultures , White Blood Cells , Dig Your Own Hole , Music for the Jilted Generation , Check Your Head/Ill Communication - these have all filtered into the collection over the last couple of years and to be quite honest I've not become sufficiently familiar with any of them to take them to heart. All the artists concerned have made much better records, and I could certainly live without them - but their presence in the stack causes me no embarrassment at all. Pulp Fiction OST - I don't feel strongly one way or the other about this compilation today. I already had Al Green's Greatest Hits, and Dusty's, and a fair stack of Surf Instrumentals. Oddly enough the track that crops up most frequently in my playlists these days is Flowers On The Wall. Go figure. Daydream Nation - this is admittedly overrated, and I still prefer everything they did pre-Geffen to anything they've done since, but it would probably make the cut even if I had to lighten my load of post-rock guitar CDs, which of course I don't... Out of Time - unfair to judge this on the basis of Radio Song, which I never liked. More than half of the remainder is excellent, and Kate Pierson was about the most inspiring vocal partner Stipey has ever collaborated with. Not my favourite REM album, nor is it the first I'd ditch (that would be, erm, lemme see... Monster, probably - itself not actually a bad album, just the least interesting thing they've done) Let It Be , Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Heart's Club Band - I've never thought much of Let It Be, and I've never considered Sgt Pepper as the Beatles' crowning achievement, or even in my favourite three Beatles records. It's one of those records that's impossible to hear, in the same way that it's impossible to see the Taj Mahal. Maybe you had to be there. Nevermind - it isn't as good as In Utero, I don't play it as often as Unplugged New York. I'd missed out on a lot of Pixies material, I had some catching up to do there - still do - but at the end of the day it is by no means a bad album. Live Through This - recently re-acquired. It doesn't sound as good as it did in 1994, sure enough, and the cover was always one of the best things about it (I would have liked a poster - I think I still would) but it's a hell of a lot better than Celebrity Skin . Bitches Brew , Giant Steps - okay so Jaguaro doesn't like jazz. I do. BB is a bit like the Sgt Pepper of fusion - not the greatest, but (one of) the first and a radical statement of intent. Try On The Corner instead. Or better still, if you share Jaguaro's antipathy towards jazz, don't bother. Transformer - this was one of the first CDs I bought, certainly one of the first CDs which I already owned on vinyl, before I prevailed upon myself not to do this unless the vinyl was seriously unplayable. Come to think of it, it was one of the first dozen or so albums that I bought, period. So, sentimentality plays a big part in my estimation here. Sure its cheesy and fey and camp - it's supposed to be! I can play this end to end - not that I do very often - and it brings back some of the better memories of being thirteen again. Dark Side of The Moon - this one has fluctuated in my estimation, over the years. I never owned a vinyl copy of it (only ever bought the Syd Barratt period on vinyl, and I think I may have picked up Meddle at some point too) but hey, I was thirteen when it came out, and back then it was everywhere. It was like the Beatles in the 60s, part of everyday life. Grateful Dead - after many long years of resistance to the Dead, I wound up with budget reissue CDs of American Beauty and Working Man's Dead, and they're both pretty decent albums. I have more affection for the (expanded) Garcia and Grisman Old and In The Way set that finally came my way early this year, but still... Finally, I completely and utterly disagree with the inclusion of Trout Mask Replica , Hunky Dory , Heaven Up Here , The Boatman's Call , On How Life Is , The Soft Bulletin and Mule Variations - these are all great albums, and with the exception of Heaven Up Here (vinyl, not in the best state of repair, one day I'll pick up the CD), albums I play frequently. Trout Mask Replica is my number one desert island disc - it shows me something new every time I play it. I've heard ignorant populists trying the Emperor's New Clothes routine on this one more than a few times before, and I've never been convinced. There are weak Beefheart albums for sure, but TMR is a long, long way from being one of them. That's the ones I have. There are others I don't have for which I would offer extenuating circumstances - I never bought Bob Marley's Legend compilation because I already owned most of it. For some years, it was the only Wailers product on the market, and if I look down the track list today I see very little that I wouldn't want to own. As a long-standing fan of jamaican music between 1960 and about 1982, I do tend to roll my eyes a bit when this is the only representative in someone's collection, but there's nothing wrong with the music itself.

urlLink Nightmare scenario of antibiotic resistance has arrived - they're heee-ere! The first confirmed case of vancomycin-resistant staph aureus bugs were found last month in a Michigan man. Vancomycin is the last-resort antibiotic, at the time of writing. The implications of this are just horrible - many surgical procedures could become too risky to be undertaken anymore, if no treatments exist to combat infections. The strain found in Michegan did in fact respond to treatment with a newer (and vastly more expensive, they'll have us know) antibiotic, linezolid - but other strains have been shown to have developed resistance to that one within a year of it hitting the market , so it's likely a super-resistant staph meeting will occur sooner rather than later. Oh, yes, that cheers me up no end.

urlLink Technology that fakes the 'truth' - David Birch at the Guardian, reviews the prospect of no longer being able to tell news from spin, following the mass availability of video editing software. This article could have been written fifteen years ago, and even then would have been thought rather old-fashioned. It is postmodernism's legitimation crisis all over again for the hard of hearing - how will you decide what is really happening? Same as before: your reality field will be pretty much owned by the media operator who devotes the most (and 'best') resources to controlling it. The truth is still, presumably, out there somewhere - but it will remain unknowable, unverifiable and possibly unrecognisable. Tou will look to your peers for validation. You will rely on trusted sources, your guru method or teacher, to tell you what's what (which makes you more vulnerable to hoodwinkery, surely?) - but you will never know. In the end, I suspect this matters less than it appears when we try to theorise our way out of the problem, because the 'problem' has been with us as long as symbolic thought...

Well, there goes another myth. urlLink Lipsum.com is a site dedicated to the "Lorem Ipsum" dummy text as used by typographers, layout artistes and web designers to designate block text provides a brief but fascinating history, and reveals that contrary to popular belief that the text is pseudo-Latin gibberish, Lorem ipsum is a bunch of fragments of Cicero's "de Finibus Bonorum et Malorum", written in 45BCE. The first section, the one that actually begins with "lorem ipsum..." translates as follows: "On the other hand, we denounce with righteous indignation and dislike men who are so beguiled and demoralized by the charms of pleasure of the moment, so blinded by desire, that they cannot foresee the pain and trouble that are bound to ensue; and equal blame belongs to those who fail in their duty through weakness of will, which is the same as saying through shrinking from toil and pain. These cases are perfectly simple and easy to distinguish. In a free hour, when our power of choice is untrammelled and when nothing prevents our being able to do what we like best, every pleasure is to be welcomed and every pain avoided. But in certain circumstances and owing to the claims of duty or the obligations of business it will frequently occur that pleasures have to be repudiated and annoyances accepted. The wise man therefore always holds in these matters to this principle of selection: he rejects pleasures to secure other greater pleasures, or else he endures pains to avoid worse pains." (1914 translation by H. Rackham)

urlLink Bush's Forest Fire Plan: Log It All A long-ish article by Jeffrey St. Clair on the history of forestry maintenance in the Western US, which underlines the total cynicism of the urlLink WMPC 's recently announced "solution" to the forest fire "problem"... In the name of fire prevention, Bush wants to okay the timber industry to log off more than 2.5 million acres of federal forest over the next ten years. He wants it done quickly and without any interference from pesky statutes such as the Endangered Species Act. Bush called his plan "the Healthy Forests Initiative". But it's nothing more than a giveaway to big timber, that comes at a high price to the taxpayer and forest ecosystems. Bush's stump speech was a craven bit of political opportunism, rivaled, perhaps, only by his call to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil drilling as a way to help heal the nation after the attacks of September 11. That plan sputtered around for awhile, but didn't go anywhere in the end. But count on it: this one will.

urlLink War of the worlds - the speculations last year concerning the origins of the name, al-Qaida have not only failed to go away, they have provided Giles Foden with the meat for an intriguing essay in yesterday's Guardian: "This peculiar coincidence would be of little interest if not for abundant parallels between the plot of Asimov's book and the events unfolding now," wrote Dmitri Gusev, the scientist who posted the article. He was referring to apparent similarities between the plot of Foundation and the pursuit of the organisation we have come to know, perhaps erroneously, as al-Qaida. The Arabic word qaida - ordinarily meaning "base" or "foundation" - is also used for "groundwork" and "basis". It is employed in the sense of a military or naval base, and for chemical formulae and geometry: the base of a pyramid, for example. Lane, the best Arab-English lexicon, gives these senses: foundation, basis of a house; the supporting columns or poles of a structure; the lower parts of clouds extending across a horizon; a universal or general rule or canon. With the coming of the computer age, it has gained the further meaning of "database": qaida ma'lumat (information base)...

urlLink urlLink This urlLink RA stream from the BBC, about US tourists making expensive pilgrimages to Wiltshire in the wake of the success of the movie Signs, really amuses me, although it's interesting to note how local businesses are adapting to the expectations of the tourists. Did these people not visit urlLink Circlemakers.org ? Did they visit and fail to understand what they were seeing? Or did they just decide to come anyway? What do they really believe? The crop circle phenomenon - by which I mean not just the creation of the patterns, but the attendant business: speculation, skepticism, 'authenticity' questions, commodification and branding - has become emblematic of the hyperreal: in order to make any kind of historical sense of it, you first would have to work out what the various participants really believe is going on, and then measure that against how they actually behave. Which would be no easy matter, to begin with. I'm not sure that walking around in patches of flattened crops would be all that satisfying, though. I'd be wanting to get up in urlLink one of these , and check them out from the air...

urlLink A new short story by Don Delillo, urlLink Looking at Meinhof . She knew there was someone else in the room. There was no outright noise, just an intimation behind her, a faint displacement of air. She'd been alone for a time, seated on a bench in the middle of the gallery with the paintings set around her, a cycle of 15 canvases, and this is how it felt to her, that she was sitting as a person does in a mortuary chapel, keeping watch over the body of a relative or a friend. She was looking at Ulrike now, head and upper body, her neck rope-scorched, although she didn't know for certain what kind of implement had been used in the hanging...

There's understandable skepticism afoot, regarding Blogcritics.com, in the comments at urlLink Blogroots . My take is in there somewhere, but I'll put it here too: I've joined up with Blogcritics.com, and in common with just about everyone who has posted to this point, my first contribution was written without any (well, without much) idea of what the site would be like. I still don't think that what we see there is 'what Blogcritics.com will be like'. I don't believe for a moment that the opinions of the Blogcritics posse, as it presently is, are worth more than anyone else's. The Blogcritics posse, in fact, cannot be said to have any idea of itself at all, at this early stage. Whether it develops one or not. remains to be seen. "A sinister cabal of the best writers on the web" is amusing hype, nothing more. I know I'm not a part of any cabal (heh - but then I would say that, wouldn't I?) I suspect that the site is as much about concentrating traffic through Blogcritics.com's Amazon affilation account as anything else. I don't mind that too much (though I'll be interested to see how much that drags in over the next three months) . I still own whatever I post, and I'm getting traffic coming to check out my blog. Where's the harm? There are good, sometimes great, conversations happening all over, I'm just looking at Blogcritics.com as another place to go and find some. A forum for general discussion will be essential. That and a lot more consideration given to the design and architecture of the site - but in the end, what's occured there is a better-than-reasonable beginning. Oh and talking about dispensing "FREE CDS!!!" at the beginning (or at all) was a big mistake, imho. Ah well.

Barberries Are Not The Only Fruit Sarah brought home a bag of tiny red fruits, labelled entirely with Arabic script. I'd seen these things in North African and Mid-Eastern cooking, but I never knew what they were called, and it took a little while before S. remembered that they are barberries. Barberries (botanical name urlLink Berberis. ) are named from the same root as the urlLink Berber (or Tamazigh for the language, or Amazigh for the people) of North Africa ( urlLink BBC World Service page ), among whom the urlLink Tuareg are numbered. The Amazigh have an urlLink Action Coalition Website whose motto reads in english: "Handle your roots and move forward" (I'm absolutely sure that's lost quite a bit in translation, but hopefully gained a little, too). There's probably an entire blog to be written about the Berber, but enough for now, back to the little red berries. The most unexpected thing I found out about barberries is that the cultivation of all species (of which there are a great many, distributed thoughout temperate climates) was urlLink banned in Canada for nearly 40 years - seems that some species are prone to a fungus that also urlLink affects cereal crops . Last year they lifted the ban on rust-resistant varieties. The barberry is a noble beast - high in vitamin C, stuffed with pectin and rather sharp tasting, they can be used to make urlLink wine , they are used as a thickening agent in urlLink jams and jellies , and there are more than a few good couscous and rice dishes: for example urlLink Tahcheen-zereshk (Rice with barberries and chicken) (This recipe gives a name, tahdeeg , to the crispy layer at the bottom of the rice pan that Iranian children squabble over. I knew about the crispy layer, and the squabbling part of it more than twenty years ago, when my old friend and flatmate Iraj taught me to cook rice in the Persian style, but he didn't tell me that the crispy layer had a name. Truly, you learn something every day). urlLink Morasah Polow is also a chicken dish and looks rather similar, but if you're vegetarian check out urlLink Morassa' Polo (Bejeweled Pilaf) - I'm definitely going to give this a go. Hmmm, Sarah's birthday tomorrow. I wonder... UPDATE: Well, I made the Morassa' Polo, with a few slight modifications: cashews for pistachios, and just the outer zesty rind of orange, rather than the whole peel. It went down very well, too... even the tahdeeg came off splendidly...

urlLink Wired 10.09: Vision Quest In 1978, shortly before the FDA passed the last in a series of medical device amendments that would outlaw testing a visual neuroprosthesis on a human, Dobelle installed his prototype into the head of a genial, big-bellied, blind Irishman from Brooklyn named Jerry. "When my grandkids meet a blind guy with a brain implant," says Jerry, explaining his participation in Dobelle's experiments, "I wanted them to be able to say, 'Let me tell you about my grandfather.'" ... Dobelle has designed a three-part system: a miniature video camera, a signal processor, and the brain implants. The camera, mounted on a pair of eyeglasses, captures the scene in front of the wearer. The processor translates the image into a series of signals that the brain can understand, then sends the information to the implant.

urlLink New Orchid Species Leaves Admirers Amazed This is a big orchid six inches across, in old money. Described as the most spectacular orchid find in the last 100 years, the new species has led to jaw-dropping effects throughout the world of orchid fanciers as word of the find has spread among the already breathless and excitable group. Even staid scientists are startled, because the new species is of an entirely unexpected color, shape and size for a Phragmipedium orchid, a group whose flowers are typically small and dull brown or green, making them the uncharismatic counterpart to the beloved lady's slipper orchid relatives farther north. urlLink O'Reilly Network: Blogging for Dollars - Giving Rise to the Professional Blogger [Aug. 12, 2002] Meg Hourihan proposes that businesses (some, not all) should hire bloggers of proven ability to blog on their behalf. She offers examples: Google coould hire someone to blog developments with the APIs, insurance companies could hire someone to blog information of interest to their actual or potential policyholders, Wine.com could hire somebody... you get the idea. I can see the benefit in the first example, but after that it gets a little muddy. Once we disregard the inconsequential chatterings of teenyboppers (I'm not knocking it, I'm really not, but I don't have to read the goddamn stuff) and the tedious 'patriotic' willy-waving of the warbloggers (ditto), the blogosphere is populated by writers who have something to say about something, and they say it, without asking anyone's permission, without having to confirm to someone else's house style, editorial policy or commercial agenda. How well or how badly they (we) do it is beside the point - but if you're employed to 'blog' on behalf of someone else's commercial interests, you are not a blogger, you are a hack, and you are not to be trusted. [IMPORTANT AFTERTHOUGHT: this comment is NOT directed at anyone in particular, especially not Meg, whose blogging is a pleasure to read :) ] Much as we would all like to be paid for the hours we spend rooting around for unconsidered truffles in the reeky wood of the web (to paraphrase Dylan Thomas) to say nothing of the time we devote to composing delicious commentary upon our prizes, what is on offer here in nothing more than a recuperation - in the Situationist sense - of the blogging phenomenon, by the greed machine. Okay, a counter-example: say I read a wine column in my paper of choice on a saturday; both the paper and the writer have a reputation for impartiality to maintain, and if it were to be discovered that the writer was taking backhanders from supermarket X Y or Z, there would be an outcry, there would be very red faces all round, the column would be history, and quite right too. Of course only the most naive of readers would imagine that the contents of the column were entirely impartial, exhaustively researched, positively the last word. Most of us would weigh up the odds, make our own judgement, perhaps based on previous recommendations that had proved reliable (or otherwise). When reading a wine company's pet 'blogger', however, almost the only thing we will know for an absolute fact that the review will be geared around selling a particular line, persuading us to buy from a particular supplier, whatever. Any reliable information gleaned from such a source would be completely fortuitous. I have first-hand knowledge of how this system works. Years ago, I wrote a few record reviews for a couple of in-store magazines. No-one ever told me what kind of a review to write, but... Behaviour modification invades at every turn. Averil, features editor at Spend magazine (acting on orders, you understand) told me today that from the next issue "we" are working a new "system" on the record reviews. I had a feeling what was coming next. And I was right. From now on there is no such thing as a bad review in Spend . They want favourable comments on all records reviewed in the magazine, and if a record is declared by the reviewer to be complete and utter crap, it goes into a side column of records "also available" without review or comment. Editorial policy at Spend is supervised in some way or other by the distributor, a major chainstore media retailer. When an editor calls one up and tells one that "we" are now working to a new "system", that from now on, records which are crap are no longer crap, they are now "also available", one naturally leans forward to examine this new "system". What manner of system is this being swung in here? Does it provide the consumer, bless him, with better information, because the news is all good? Does anyone get to find out what a record is like? Does it enhance, or does it undermine the credibility of the reviews that are included? Are we critics, or are we advertising copy writers? Are we paid to be advertising copy writers?

Something for the weekend, sir? urlLink smattering.org >the friday five 1. Do you have a car? If so, what kind off car is it? No car, for about nine years now. 2. Do you drive very often? Very rarely. 3. What's your dream car? Quiet, clean technology. Maintainable. And inconspicuous, on grounds of ubiquity. 4. Have you ever received a ticket? Yup. Brownie points for speeding one time. 5. Have you ever been in an accident? The most spectacular accident I was in involved crashing, spinning and rolling a Lada estate I'd had a month, on an icy back road in Wales. No other vehicles around, suddenly there was no steering, and there were no brakes. Hit a hedge, then another hedge, then rolled it over. I sat there with my eyes open, watching the world around me go crazy, thinking, the lights could go out any time now... when everything stopped, I was still holding the wheel, and there wasn't a scratch on either myself or my passenger, who was unrolling from a foetal crouch as I looked around. Actually, no - the last joint of my little finger, right hand, became a little swollen for a few days, probably from gripping the wheel too hard. The radio was still on. The ground was back where it belonged; we were facing the wrong way in a lane narrow enough to make it extremely difficult to turn around in, at least at ground level. The car was totalled. I mean, not just a little bit. It didn't move of it's own volition ever again...

I'm not sure what I'm getting into here. I don't mean the music reviewing part; I used to to it for a living. What I mean is, I've jumped aboard urlLink Eric Olsen's blogcritics.com wheeze , without any clear idea of where it's heading. After reading his and other people's posts on the subject, I'm not that convinced that anyone else has much more of an idea than I do, either, but let's roll with it. I've assured Eric that I'd put up some kind of music review by Friday, and Friday it is. Why not start with an album that did more than any other to broaden my musical (and intellectual, and possibly political) horizons? "Her influence today is undeniable," said Michael Stipe of REM, "There' s not anybody I know in a band anywhere who not revere the records that she put out. There was a rawness and energy to Horses that I had not heard in any other music. From then on, my life was changed." My introduction to Patti Smith was Charles Shaar Murray's urlLink review of urlLink Horses in the NME, November 1975. That would have made me, ooh, sixteen and a half at the time. I probably had no more than a couple of dozen albums to my name back then, and a third of those would have been Bowie (so the sexual ambiguity - such an important part of what made Bowie so striking in the early 70s - was already a feature in the landscape). It took two months for copies of Horses to appear in the shops in Liverpool, and when I got it home and played Gloria for the first time, I was anxious, first of all, that I hadn't put too much faith in CSM's persuasion. This was the first time I'd ever bought a record by an artist I'd never heard, simply on the basis of a piece of rock journalism, and a brand new release at that. I probably paid what, two and a half quid for it, which was money in those days... Well, the music was ragged: guitars thrust out at peculiar angles, the piano sounded like it was actually prowling around the studio. And Patti's voice, my God, and urlLink the things she said . "Jesus died for somebody's sins, but not mine..." no-one has opened their debut album with such a radical (and true) statement of intent, before or since. It was quite a shock to the system. It completely shattered whatever preconceptions I might have had about what rock music could do, what it could contain, what it could promise and more to the point, what it could deliver: passion, poetry and intelligence all at the same time - and once the strangeness had subsided, it became perfectly clear that you could, after all, dance to it. Patti Smith turned out to be the flip-side (good grief, I'm regressing into vinyl-speak!) of glam: literate, allusive, predatory and strident, in a good way. She was utterly unlike any woman I'd ever seen in rock music before. Even if I'd known of Janis Joplin at the time (I probably didn't), any comparison would have been fatuous: Patti was totally in charge of herself, she projected a vision of deliverance and redemption through rock'n'roll, and unlike Bowie, there was no trace of ironic distance - bear in mind that at this point in Bowie's career, Young Americans was the latest release, and while it was all fine and interesting, he seemed to be receding into thinness (and whiteness, and erm, dukishness) it looked like ironic distance was all we had left of him. Horses provided a set of clues that continued to unravel and offer leads into unknown territory for years afterwards. (Oh and the second album, urlLink Radio Ethiopia , is just as good, except of course that you can never experience that shock of awakening in quite the same way, after the first time...)

The bad news is that NewBreed Librarian is giving up the ghost just as I stumble across it. The good news is that they have a new issue to offer as a parting gift, which includes an urlLink interview with Eric Miller (W3C Activity Lead on the urlLink Semantic Web Initiative in which the rudiments of SW are explained. Oh and can I take this opportunity, since I'm looking at an example of it right now, to register a little irritation over CSS that disturbs the rendering of innocent block text? For example: a:link {font-weight: bold; text-decoration: none;} a:visited {text-decoration: none; } a:hover { font-weight: bold; text-decoration: underline; } - links are ordinarily displayed in bold, but once visited are no longer bold - except when rolled over, when they revert to bold again, causing the paragraph to wobble about as the browser adjusts to accommodate. Changes to the font-size on :hover are the same, only worse. It really bugs me, and I know enough to understand why it's happening. I can see something like this really upsetting and confusing to someone who's new to it all, and they're wondering, in that endearing, panic-stricken way that they have, why the text is leaping about for no apparent reason. It would be okay if it looked cool, but does it? Ever? Just thought I'd share...

urlLink Modern Enchantments James Flint reviews what looks very much like a revisionist account of the power of media in Simon During's Modern Enchantments, which provides lots of interesting material from the history of (secular) illusionism, but argues that audiences are culturally equipped to enter into, and then discard whatever conceits that media lays before them. During's implication is that there is something fundamentally flawed about the contention made by critics from Siegfried Kracauer (who in 1927 analysed the high kicks of dancing girls as "the rational and empty form of the cult"), through Debord, Baudrillard and Virilio, that commercial cinema represents the "triumph of the spectacle"; that it is not an exercise in secular magic but in power magic, the most overt manifestations of which are the Nazi propaganda films of Leni Riefenstahl.

urlLink I Understand Philip K. Dick by Terence McKenna One sadly-departed, sorely-missed wild-eyed visionary nutter appreciates another: Phil wasn’t nuts. Phil was a vortex victim.* Schizophrenia is not a psychological disorder peculiar to human beings. Schizophrenia is not a disease at all but rather a localized traveling discontinuity of the space time matrix itself. It is like a travelling whirl-wind of radical understanding that haunts time. It haunts time in the same way that Alfred North Whitehead said that the color dove grey "haunts time like a ghost."

urlLink Stone River at Stanford Stanford, CA, Sept. 4, 2001—In late August, British artist Andy Goldsworthy (born 1956) completed Stone River, a 320-foot sculpture on the campus of Stanford University. Constructed of sandstone from university buildings destroyed in the 1906 and 1989 earthquakes, Stone River is the largest work of outdoor art at the university. In addition to Goldsworthy, a team of eight professional dry-stone wallers from England and Scotland worked 11 hours a day, six days a week, for three and a half weeks (1848 hours) to complete the sculpture on schedule.

Leafing through Euen Semple's recent-ish posts, I find a recommendation of urlLink Jonathan Delacour's blog , where in turn I find urlLink this , quoted by Mark Pilgrim in early August, which Mark found tucked into the XML source code for his Dive Into Python (presumably Mark's own words, then, although he doesn't say definitely). The final sentence is as elegant and concise an approach to time management as any I have seen; it expresses my feeling about time management, which I recall promising to go away and think about, which I did, and to come back and let you know my conclusions, if any, which I didn't, mainly because my conclusion was pretty facetious: "decide what doesn't need to be done, and go right ahead without delay, and not do it". This is a lot better: As I write this, the year is 2000, and the Internet is a battleground of intellectual property disputes. Some people would like you to believe that, without proper financial incentives, music, literature, and computer software would disappear. After all, who would make music if they can't make money on it? Who would write? Who would program? I know the answer. The answer is that musicians will make music, not because they can make money, but because musicians are the people who can't not make music. Writers will write because they can't not write. I?ve been programming for 16 years, writing free software for 8. I can?t imagine not doing this. If you can imagine yourself not doing what you're doing, do something else. Do whatever it is that you can't not do.

urlLink Guardian Unlimited | Special reports | Hypocrisy is on the march Zoe Williams in the Guardian, echoing my thoughts as the numbers at the countryside march in London were announced: When it comes to public protest, there are some irritating double-standards in this country, of which the most immediately irritating is this: on Sunday, the police estimated 300,000 at the Countryside Alliance march, where the organisers counted 400,000. Fair enough. There is always a counting discrepancy between the police and the marchers, though on leftwing protests it is usually rather larger (the police used to put CND marches at 30,000, roughly the size of a football crowd, which made their ability to fill Hyde Park and beyond nothing short of miraculous). Yesterday morning, however, newspapers were quoting as fact the final figure of 407,791; the Metropolitan police had brought their estimate up to 400,000, presumably because these are people in tweeds and therefore cannot be lying. This may, as so many point out, be the largest peaceful protest in British history, but it's also the first British protest in history where everyone agreed how large it was...

urlLink "What is a saint? A saint is someone who has achieved a remote human possibility. It is impossible to say what that possibility is. I think it has something to do with the energy of love. Contact with this energy results in the exercise of a kind of balance in the chaos of existence. A saint does not dissolve the chaos; if he did the world would have changed long ago. I do not think that a saint dissolves the chaos even for himself, for there is something arrogant and warlike in the notion of a man setting the universe in order. It is a kind of balance that is his glory. He rides the drifts like an escaped ski. His course is the caress of the hill. His track is a drawing of the snow in a moment of its particular arrangement with wind and rock. Something in him so loves the world that he gives himself to the laws of gravity and chance. Far from flying with the angels, he traces with the fidelity of a seismograph needle the state of the solid bloody landscape. His house is dangerous and finite, but he is at home in the world. He can love the shape of human beings, the fine and twisted shapes of the heart. It is good to have among us such men, such balancing monsters of love." [ Beautiful Losers (1966) ]

urlLink On the road to nowhere Iain Sinclair interviewed, as the publication date of his latest psychogeographic investigation, urlLink London Orbital , draws near. I've found that I prefer Sinclair's psychogeography over the fiction (although I've yet to read urlLink White Chappell, Scarlet Tracings ); the style is more pumped up in the fiction (it's a style that can definitely be overdone, as certain sections of urlLink Downriver attest) and I find many of his characters impenetrable, but the psychogeography books totally boil what remains of my brains. London Orbital promises a visit with J.G Ballard, lots of Bram Stoker, the site of the first Martian invasion, from H.G. Wells' War of The Worlds, and yes, if you're reading this in some professional capacity, a review copy would be very nice indeed. The following gives indication of how much I'm looking forward to it. Somehow I'd managed not to read any Sinclair at all until about three years ago; I knew the name, and I had some indication that his work would be of interest, but still, I didn't crack the spine of a Sinclair book until my good friend Clive in Wales gave me the kind of recommendation of urlLink Lights Out For The Territory that only a complete idiot would ignore, and my idiocy is... incomplete. So I bought the book, read the book and called Clive to enthuse. "You know he's reading here tomorrow night?" said Clive. "What!? I'll be there!" I said. The next day I went into work with my bag packed. Sorry to spring it on you like this, but I have to be in Aberystwyth tonight. I'll be back this tomorrow lunchtime. "Er, okay", they said, and I was gone. urlLink Here's a picture I took on the train, some village in Herefordshire, moving at speed. I was there in time to meet up with Clive, IS and others for a drink before the gig (and by happy coincidence, urlLink Niall Griffiths was reading in town that evening too, and so we checked that out) and then up the hill to the Aber Arts Centre and this is urlLink himself, silhouetted against projected video noise , during the reading/screening, 9th November... hmmm, 9-11-99 in UK date order... It was an expensive trip, in the end - I think I must have spent about £80 on books apart from anything else - but I don't have as many exciting adventures as I used to, so I like to make the most of them when they come along.

I don't know how it's been around your neighbourhood this week, but around here, some people have been losing it; being on the verge of it, and then suddenly, not being on the verge anymore. People have been snapping like twigs. And so it is, as it happens, in the ever more brutal world of mainstream TV entertainment. In urlLink The Chair , a new game show on the BBC with John McEnroe (no lie), contestants are required to keep their heart rate below a critical level whilst answering mostly multiple choice questions, and smiling indulgently through MacEnroe's rather tedious bantering. this show appears to reward a "skill" that might otherwise be interpreted as, well, a bit sociopathic ... I wonder how many they've auditioned to camera? I wonder how many they've screened in total, and how. I bet a documentary plunge into those stats could be made an awful lot more interesting than this bogus quiz show with a tacky set, and John MacEnroe reminding us every ninety seconds that he used to lose it now and then? I only mention it because seeing a show like this isn't that frequent an occurence for me, so its noteworthy to me, but I wouldn't expect it to be a regular feature or anything. There's a urlLink flash version online, but I don't think I can have understood it very well, because I failed that that even more miserably than I would imagine failing in the TV game, and that's saying something... urlLink Adding considerably to the freak-out theme, Sarah brought round a library copy of urlLink Themroc (1972) which is a truly startling experience: Michel Piccoli totally freaking out & going feral, from a standing start in a mundane contemporary existence. And then people begin to follow his example... It comes apart a bit in the closing stages, lapsing into a rather portentous, heavy-handed conclusion - it can't be easy deciding where to stop with a movie like this - but the first two thirds of it are brilliant, raging, extraordinary. There's a review urlLink here , and another one, more substantial but on a lime green page, urlLink here . Oh yes, and - one of the first things I intended to mention about this movie - it's the only one I've ever seen where the language classification on the case says, and I quote: "Gibberish" - there are almost no intelligible words in the script. All characters communicate and express themselves non-verbally throughout. Absolutely, anthropologically compelling.

Well, it's a beautiful morning here in Sydenham, just like it was a year ago. The sky is clear and blue just like it was then. I'd just had a very pleasant lunch with some ex-colleagues, and I'd walked down to Camberwell Green afterwards. I was in the act of buying a secondhand copy of Joy Division's Still when the guy behind the counter asked me if I'd heard the news, and his account was pretty accurate, as it turned out. Fuuuuck, I remarked. I got on the bus home and stared out of the window, knowing that I'd just heard about something enormous, that things would be different from now on. When I got home, I switched on the TV, and it stayed on for about 36 hours straight. I haven't played that CD yet. For a while the only thing I could listen to was Jan Garbarek's Officium - and then later, the song that came to represent what happened (as much for the subliminal references as anything) in my head: Well I think it's fine, building jumbo planes. Or taking a ride on a cosmic train. Switch on summer from a slot machine. Get what you want to if you want, 'cause you can get anything. I know we've come a long way, We're changing day to day, But tell me, where do the children play?

Well, I'm back, and while I was gone, I actually finished a book. (This doesn't happen very often lately; I used to do most of my book reading on public transport on the way to and from work, which as you may have gathered, no longer applies.) The book I finished was urlLink Not The End of The World (Christopher Brookmyre 1998) which I picked up from a local charity shop, after seeing it recommended by urlLink Charlie Stross . It's pretty much your standard millennial doomsday thriller: there's a dastardly plot to cause a massive tidal wave to engulf Los Angeles - I don't think I'm spoiling anything here; the True Nature of the Dastardly Plot is pretty well apparent to anyone who reads say, the first three chapters - but the point of the novel is a tirade against religion in general, and Christianity in particular. The tirade aspect of the book is by far the most effective, imho. The plot's... just a plot; there are conspicuously missed chances in both story and character devolopment, and some of the dialogue falters badly (LA cops using words and phrases that I doubt very much LA cops would ever use) but when Brookmyre gets into rant mode, the writing really takes off. - the porn star's withering denunciation of the TV evangelist - don't worry, you'll know it when you see it - is an absolute delight. I think I might have had to wipe away a tear. Would I read more? I might. Brookmyre gives good outrage, and the rhythm of the sections told from the viiew of the Scottish photographer (with whom Brookmyre clearly and unapologetically identifies, no blame there) are more successful than some others. Perhaps I've just started with a book in which he's slightly over-reached himself; I'd very much like to see what he did with subject matter that's a bit closer to home.

urlLink peter greenaway: monsters of macon A short but pithy interview, originally from 1994, and posted last November. The main issue at the time was a defence of his (then) latest film, The Baby of Macon, which had been denounced even by a number of his close collaborators. "Often it's the Church who is using the phenomenon of terror and horror in a deeply voyeuristic way to parade its own propaganda - we are prepared to cathartically take ourselves to the edge of human experience, but without responsibility. Television sets every night show us all sorts of terrifying things that happen in Rwanda, South Africa, the Middle East and we don't all have sufficient information and intelligence to separate what is fact from so-called truth and pictorial representation. Those edges become blurred as our anxiety about the education and involvement of children revolves around the perception of what is representation and what isn't. So I make a self-conscious cinema that is saying, "I can play with illusionism, you can be a voyeur, but let's take responsibility of it," because my film doesn't exist without you--the audience--and you are just as much a participant in this as I am."

Just when hopes were fading that I'd find something to really excite me (and therefore, you) on the web today last night, I discovered urlLink The Zymoglyphic Museum , which is an absolute delight to an old urlLink Joseph Cornell fan such as myself. The museum is (mostly) the work of one Jim Stewart, who has been making art from found objects, with particular reference to the decayed, distressed and broken, since childhood - although how long ago that was is not divulged. The work occupies a place somewhere along the line between Cornell and urlLink The Brothers Quay . Ordinarily, the museum is only to be found online, because the works are too fragile for straightforward exhibition, but there is to be a showing "probably the first weekend of May 2003" at the urlLink Silicon Valley Open Studios . Two sections of the online museum, however, are not Stewart's work, although they are clearly related: there's a small collection of Xenophora assemblages - the work of a species of marine snail which attaches bits of debris to its shell, probably either for camouflage or to stop them from sinking into the soft mud they inhabit. There's also a section devoted to the work of eccentric 17th anatomist and tissue preservation pioneer urlLink Frederik Ruysch (1638-1731), who constructed tableaux of foetal skeletons and used hardened, preserved body parts - lungs, major veins and so on - as landscape features. Quite a way further out than Herr von Hagens' urlLink Body Worlds show... (via urlLink Everlasting Blortzilla )

Samhain I'm irritated by the urlLink Salon article which makes the astonishing claim that Halloween was invented in 1929 - and then goes on to discuss its ancient history. Sure they say, but that wasn't Halloween as we know it... well, duh. This is rather like saying that Easter is "about" eggs made of chocolate. Or that Christmas is "about" a fat bloke in a red and white costume (which dates back to a Coca Cola as campaign in the 1920s - before then, Santa's costume was no particular colour. But I digress). Even the Christianised versions of these festivals, from which the Day of the Dead festivals arise, and which have no great claim to authenticity in themselves, are ancient by the Walmart standards which obtain in this article. Samhain is the cross-quarter festival which marks the beginning of winter and of the ancient Celtic new year. Here's the section of Frazer's The Golden Bough that deals with urlLink Hallowe’en (as unearthed by urlLink Eeksy Peeksy ): The principal fire-festivals of the Celts, which have survived, though in a restricted area and with diminished pomp, to modern times and even to our own day, were seemingly timed without any reference to the position of the sun in the heaven. They were two in number, and fell at an interval of six months, one being celebrated on the eve of May Day and the other on Allhallow Even or Hallowe’en, as it is now commonly called, that is, on the thirty-first of October, the day preceding All Saints’ or Allhallows’ Day. These dates coincide with none of the four great hinges on which the solar year revolves, to wit, the solstices and the equinoxes. Nor do they agree with the principal seasons of the agricultural year, the sowing in spring and the reaping in autumn. For when May Day comes, the seed has long been committed to the earth; and when November opens, the harvest has long been reaped and garnered, the fields lie bare, the fruit-trees are stripped, and even the yellow leaves are fast fluttering to the ground...

urlLink Traditionally, the method of learning Chinese calligraphy has two main elements: one is to train technical skills, the other is to train the mind. Once they complement each other, it is thought a student will arrive at a higher level of the art of calligraphy. The former element is about the physical, i.e. exercising the muscles to develop one’s expressiveness, based upon the correct motions of writing developed with long practice, which matures with age. This could be seen in Western terms, as related to Baudelaire’s comment: "the grandiloquent truth of gestures on life’s great occasions. (Baudelaire in Barthes, 1957)" Learning calligraphy is like learning Chinese boxing, it is a matter of developing the correct writing techniques through the practice of the muscles of the fingers, wrist, arm, elbow and the waist. So, it is said without determined practice it is very difficult to emulate good handwriting. The latter element is about personal accomplishment and self-cultivation, which can be divided into moral standing and knowledge. According to the Chinese ancients, if ‘a person has no grand moral character, the writing has no splendor’. In calligraphic thought this means that one can not depart from one’s times, violate nature, desert life, disobey one’s country and one’s society, but be full of the substance and beauty of life.

Further to yesterday's link ramblings, I should certainly take a good long look at Claire Harrison's paper at First Monday urlLink Whither Thou Goest, And Why : The question then arises: Is it actually possible to create a hypertext that is not idiosyncratic in some manner? I suggest that it is not. Whether a site contains pages and/or databases, the decision regarding what is to be included is always based on human choice which is inherently idiosyncratic. For example, let us say that a government database includes the biographies of all elected politicians. Not only has someone decided that such information should be on the site, the biographies themselves are tainted, so to speak, by the writer(s) who have decided what information should or should not be included in them. Even simple facts can pose difficulties. Say, the government database also included a link to all votes by elected politicians within a given Congress. The "yeas" and "nays" are facts, but such facts are only the foundation of interpretation, discussion, and/or argument for which they require context. Yet, the minute the user can link to contextual information, e.g., the politics of the day, the dynamics of the particular Congress, each politician's political affiliation, and so forth, the information is once again "tainted." As Nelson (1999) noted, "'Information,' referred to as a commodity, is a myth. Information always comes in packages ... and every such package has a point of view. Even a database has a point of view."

Want to fritter away a pleasant afternoon, and drive yourself close to the brink of insanity while you're about it? Here's a little game you can play: make a list of all the blogs with whom you are mutually linked. (Enthusiasm has 24 of these) check out everyone's blogroll, and find who among them is mutually linked to whom it might help to begin by disregarding mutual links of yours that don't link to anyone else in your roll... You come up with a strange crystalline structure in your head, in which one or more groups of blogs are interconnected by mutual linkage. There will others who link partially to those groups. These are bloggers for whom introductions and specific recommendations could be made. Make a note of these. There may also be blogs who are mutually linked by members of your groups which you don't link, or maybe have never noticed before. These are interesting blogs; make a note of these, too. things get quite quickly out of hand. You start wishing you had a little script to automate some of this blogroll-crawling. urlLink a liquid computer Well, this is very interesting. Take a pile of Perspex tubes, a few levers and pulleys and the windscreen-wiper pumps from an old wartime bomber. If the government raises taxes or the public goes on a spending spree, then this bizarre bit of plumbing shows what happens to the country’s savings and investments. At a quick flick of a switch the strange contraption can reveal the wisdom of increasing government spending or the folly of cutting interest rates. This huge machine, knocked up in a barrage by one-time crocodile hunter Bill Phillips, is now on display at the urlLink Science Museum in London. But in the 1950s, the computer model that ran on water was streets ahead of its electronic contemporaries.

I slept for a long time last night, stumbled out of bed not that long ago... SMS about earthquakes in Manchester (didn't that happen already?) and rewound the VCR. C4 repeated a documentary/interview with Alan Moore at some ridiculous hour of the night. Anyway I started watching it before I'd even revived myself with my morning pot of tea. This would be a really bad idea for almost any activity except getting a nudge in the ribs from a magus: Magick has quote a lot in common with fiction and with fantasy. We almost get to the notion that the two are pretty well interchangeable. I think Aleister Crowley mentions that the language of magick is more about language than it is about magick. The idea of a grimoire, a dark book of spells - grimoire is just another way of spelling grammar. According to Crowley, to cast a spell is simply, 'to spell'. When we think of the fact that most of the magick gods that various cultures have created or worshipped in the past - characters like Mercury, Hermes, Thoth - these are not only the gods of magick, they are also the scribe gods, the gods of writing. To some degree, the reason I involve myself with magick is that partly as a writer I was feeling that something to do with the territory of writing itself, the way that anyone who has been writing for a given length of time will have anecdotes to tell you, strange little coincidences, things that they wrote and then something very similar happened to them, perhaps a day, perhaps a month, perhaps ten years later. There are these odd little incidents that tend to build up that you tend to shove in a filing drawer just marked 'weird stuff' and eventually, as with myself, you might reach a point where you decide that the stuff in the drawer marked weird stuff is in fact the only important stuff, and that if you wish to progress as a writer beyond mere technique, you might be advised to start looking at some of those events...

Generally, every fruit, on ripening, and just before it falls, when it commences a more independent and individual existence, requiring less nourishment from any source, and that not so much from the earth through its stem as from the sun and air, acquires a bright tint. urlLink Mark Wood has a clutch of links this morning on the subject of enthusiasm. It's a word with a complex and fascinating history, as suggested by the succession of meanings given in the definition that sits beneath the blogroll over there in the navigation column. Prior to the eighteenth century, the word stood for something like religious frenzy, inspired by a (supposed) divine revelation. In this sense, an enthusiast was considered someone dangerously unhinged, a loose cannon, a public order crisis-in-waiting. During the transition into the Romantic period, however, the word acquired a secular meaning, denoting the motive force of poetic creativity - and the boundaries and distinctions between the two senses were jealously guarded (from the religious side of the argument, at least). The most substantial of Mark's references, and the richest source of quotes on the subject, is an article by Jon Mee from urlLink Romanticism On The Net 25 (February 2002) , entitled urlLink Mopping Up Spilt Religion: The Problem of Enthusiasm 'By 1735, the Gentleman's Magazine could publish a definition of enthusiasm in terms of "any exorbitant monstrous Appetite of the human Mind"... Two years later, the same magazine reported a parliamentary speech confirming that "the lowest Class of People [...] have, generally speaking a turn to Enthusiasm, and so strong is the Influence, such is the force of Delusion, that they can work themselves up to a firm Persuasion and thorough belief that any Mischief they are able to do, is not only lawful but laudable"...For the Romantic period, whether in its religious or secular forms, enthusiasm remained dangerously intertwined with the idea of the being transported into the amorphous and unstable hyper-sociability of the crowd.'

urlLink Evolution and Literary Criticism A most interesting article which appears to call for a Darwinian literary analysis. Although most scholars give lip service to the merits of "interdisciplinary" study, all too often such efforts are only celebrated when they involve poaching on another discipline's preserve. Thus, current literary criticism seems eager to "deconstruct the texts" of natural and social scientists, while considering their own domain sacrosanct. What about some traffic in the other direction, all the while fully admitting that evolutionary insights will not exhaust the rich body of human literary imaginings, any more than the science of optics contains all that might be said about sunsets? We come to expand and enhance literary criticism, not to limit it.

Back hurting yesterday becomes severe back pain today, and a deadline looming for tomorrow. Hence the lack of bloggage. What follows is a little impoverished, linkwise, for which even more apologies... Okay, Megalithomania report. I caught eight of the presentations, but missed the evening's music and film screenings. What I did see amounted to a broad introduction to a range of viewpoints on mindfully marking the landscape with stones, monuments, power spots, boundaries and alignments. Andy Letcher spoke of the relationship between paganism and protest culture, specifically urlLink environmental , urlLink anti-road protests . Rob Stephenson gave a lightning run-through of myth and legend surrounding the early history of London (I'll be unpacking the notes from his talk very carefully over several days, lest they detonate an information explosion in my head that would take over my entire life). After lunch, Leslie Ellen Jones gave a most amusing account of the strange uses to which the film and televison business have made over the years, which rather underlined the wildly divergent, sometimes nonsensical interpretations which inform some understanding of megaliths. Followed by a supporting program of cheesy film clips, the cheesiest of which by far was urlLink Psychomania! Alan Walker spoke of Christian stonework, and the inscription of parish boundary markers in London, which might make an interesting psychogeography project for someone. Robert Wallis described the fraught relationship between the conflicting cultures of Engliish Heritage (the Quango in charge of management of historic and prehistoric sites in general, and the pagan communities who actually use certain sites for their ritual observances, some of which bear scant resemblance to the sombre repressed devotions of High C of E., which brings a whole other set of problems. Then Iain Sinclair described an arc of London's Orbital From the intersection of the Greenwich meridian around to Shenley, where Nicholas Hawksmoor is buried. There may be an excerpt from the book knocking about somewhere. Paul Devereux showed a bewildering variety of sacred sites, to a greater or lesser extent transforming the landscape and defining vantage points from which communication with the infinite, giving example of sites which replicate folk memory of the original High Places. Then it was tea time, and I went home.

urlLink Death of an idea Julian Baggini steps up to bang another nail in the coffin of postmodernism. As these things go, it's a very similar argument to the ones advanced a year ago, and reviewed by urlLink Stanley Fish in the New York Times. I don't find it anymore convincing now than I did then. Surely postmodernism is being misrepresented when it is accused of actually denying the existence of "objective" reality? If I understand correctly, the existence of an objective reality is not really (heh!) in dispute - only the belief in the attainability of a single authoritative and exhaustive model of that reality. What's that Karl Popper word? Verisimilitude. That's the one. All of our understandings, or mappings of reality are culturally derived, and more fundamentally, contingent on the particular sensory and cognitive apparatus with which we are equipped. A good map is one that helps us get to where we want to go. A map that works. "Truth", or verisimilitude, only becomes an issue as and when the map fails. Wherupon the map may be revised - but the new map is more "true" only to the extent that it is more "useful"... (via urlLink Phil & Lit )

urlLink International Dunhuang Project In 1900 a hidden cave was discovered at a Buddhist site near the ancient Silk Road town of Dunhuang. Sealed in about 1000 AD, it contained tens of thousands of manuscripts, paintings and printed documents on paper and silk dating from 400-1000 AD. The world’s earliest and largest paper archive, the cave’s contents included many unique documents, including the world’s earliest dated printed book (868 AD). The majority were in Chinese, but there was a large collection of Tibetan documents as well as items in Turkic Uighur and several other languages.

urlLink new books: Surrealist Subversions From its auspicious beginnings in the summer of 1966 to the present, the Chicago Surrealist Group -- and the Surrealist Movement in the United States, which grew out of it -- have continued to foment an exhilarating whirlwind of revolt while playfully igniting the sparks of Poetry, Freedom and Love in the crucible of the Unfettered Imagination. In so doing, it has brightly illuminated the pathways of absolute divergence that define the intrinsically anarchist trajectory of the surrealist adventure. Drawing on the full range of U.S. surrealist publications, from the original journal Arsenal/Surrealist Subversion to the very latest millennial communiques from the front lines of the ongoing battle against miserabilism, this volume contains over 200 texts (many appearing here for the first time) by more than fifty participants in the Surrealist Movement, making this the most comprehensive, diverse and lavishly illustrated compilation of American surrealist writings ever to be assembled.

urlLink I don't think I've found any edible wild mushrooms in London until today, but look - Shaggy Ink Cap, or Lawyer's Wig, Coprinus comatus (click for actual size) in perfect condition. I wish I could scan the smell of them for you. These mushrooms turn into an unappetising black goop rather quickly, and although they remain urlLink edible until they begin to blacken and liquefy, they are really good when the gills are still pale and the caps relatively unopened, like these. Even better, I found them only three minutes' walk away from here, and there's more coming! Now that's much better than a scan of my poor, injured, still throbbing finger would have been, don't you think? UPDATE: I cooked the mushrooms in butter with garlic and parsley. Like many wild mushrooms, they gave off a good quantity of liquid, so I let them simmer away for rather longer than I would usually cook mushrooms, so the liquor reduced. Then stirred in beaten eggs and black pepper to make an omelette of it all. The ink caps had a pleasant, delicate flavour, quite nutty, rather like almonds in fact, which nevertheless lingers almost an hour after I've eaten the dish. Of course I had no sooner eaten my wild mushroom omelette than I succumbed to Wild Mushroom Anxiety. I become briefly convinced that I have made a fatal error of identification, and that I am about to die a horrible and lingering toxic death. I get this every goddamn time I have wild fungus to eat - at least, every time I try a new species, or from a new source. Then I forget all about it until the next time...sigh.

It's been a busy day. We've moved Sarah from Willesden, which is north west London, over to Forest Hill, which is fifteen minutes' walk down the road from here in the south east. It all went swimmingly, except that when we arrived at the new place, your humble narrator tried to open a sash window. I slipped the catch, and the top half of the window - controversially not equipped with the ropes and counterweights that make sash windows actually work - crashed down on the middle two fingers of my left hand like a guillotine. Fortunately it only caught the fingers on the nails - and if you ever whacked your fingernail with a hammer, you'll have some idea what that felt like. I wasn't what you would call conversational for quite a while. There followed a miraculously brief visit to the hospital - I think we were in and out of there within about half an hour, which these days is absolutely unheard of. The receptionist told Sarah while I was getting treatment that they'd dealt with all the saturday night injuries by that point, except for the ones who had yet to wake up and decide that they needed medical attention, so my little accident was perfectly timed to avoid the rush. My left hand ring finger is throbbing like something out of a Tom & Jerry cartoon, but here I am, actually typing with it, so I expect I'll be fine in a day or two...

urlLink Brewster Kahle interview The Wayback Machine man talks to New Scientist. The ground covered is pretty basic, but we shouldn't neglect the basics, should we? Websites are like shifting sands. The average life of a Web page is 100 days. After that either it's changed or it disappears. So our intellectual society is built on sand. You can't hold people accountable if, say, the promises posted on the Web by politicians are not available after the election. And key academic papers can become unavailable if a researcher leaves a university and their website is deleted. We've found that many websites of publicly funded projects disappear within a year. So as taxpayers we are investing in research projects, but we're not investing in a Web library that organises them and gives future generations access. Our Wayback Machine is the first attempt to do this.

urlLink Guardian Unlimited Film | Interviews | Michael Moore This interview is dated 11th November. I'm not sure how I missed it until now, but I'm very glad I didn't miss it completely. I think they're very afraid of this film - they've been afraid of it since Cannes and they've been trying to figure out how to control it. Because it's not a gun control movie - this is a movie which says that something is more seriously and deeply wrong with the USA and our gun problem is a symptom of the larger illness that exists. Charlton Heston said in this interview with me, with no prompting from me, that the problem with America is "our mixed ethnicity". I'd asked a question about why Canadians don't have as many gun murders as we do and he said he was very proud that our country had been invented by those wise and dead white guys. And he kept making these kind of racial comments, but then he'd back off from them when I repeated the question to him. People were very afraid as to how that was going to come across. I don't know why anybody would feel sorry for a guy who leads the most powerful lobby group in the US and whose sole purpose is to make sure that people can have as many guns as they want to have and fire as many bullets as the guns can possibly fire. These people are insane and they have to be stopped.

urlLink Zapruder Film Frames 39 years ago today in Dealey Plaza, JFK shot dead by person or persons unknown, givng rise to the conspiracy theory leisure industry. My recommended reading? Don Delillo's fictional biography of the putative perp / patsy, Lee Harvey Oswald, in urlLink Libra : Nicholas Branch in his glove-leather armchair is a retired senior analyst of the Central Intelligence Agency, hired on contract to write the secret history of the assassination of President Kennedy. Six point nine seconds of heat and light. Let's call a meeting to analyze the blur. Let's devote our lives to understanding this moment, separating the elements of each crowded second. We will build theories that gleam like jade idols, intriguing systems of assumption, four faced, graceful. We will follow the bullet trajectories backwards to the lives that occupy the shadows, actual men who moan in their dreams. Elm Street. A woman wonders why she is sitting on the grass, blooodspray all around. Tenth Street. A witness leaves her shoes on the hood of a bleeding policeman's car. A strangeness, Branch feels, that is almost holy. There is much here that is holy, an aberration in the heartland of the real. Let's regain our grip on things.
